description.narrative:
This project is implemented by Oxfam in Vietnam under the MARP programme, and funded by the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) and Oxfam Hong Kong. The overall goal of the project is to reduce poverty, increase livelihood diversification and enhance resilience of ethnic minorities and women in the poorest and marginalized up-land areas of Vietnam, through pro-poor value chain development of rattan and Lung bamboo. Total approved budget of US$1,342,394 (SDC funded US$831,732 and OHK and others contribute US$510,662).
Approach The project works to achieve three outcomes: 1. Increased annual income for ethnic minorities and poor women from sustainable production and marketing of rattan and Lung raw material. 2. Increased annual income for ethnic minorities and poor women through value addition of rattan and Lung products, and 3. Promoted enabling environment to support pro-poor rattan and Lung value chain development from local to regional level.
Target Groups The project targets poor upland ethnic minorities and women as actors along rattan and bamboo value chain including growers, producers, collectors, pre-processors and traders. The project directly targets four districts in Nghe An province: Que Phong, Quy Chau, Tuong Duong and Con Cuong.
Expected Results The project aims for a30-40% increase in the annual income of about 2,500 to 3,000 poor upland ethnic minorities and women through increasing their access to the rattan and bamboo value chain in Nghe An province. Directbenefits from this project will include increased and sustainable collective commercial production, improved processing and design of manufactured goods, stronger bargaining power and long-term contractual arrangements with traders and manufacturers, in-depth market analysis and ensured capacity to respond to its fluctuations (particularly in view of the envisaged increase of production from seedlings up to final handicraft products). This project will create permanent employment for 520 persons: 80 in nursery establishment (full-time), 40 in rattan processing (50% time), 200 in Lung processing (60% time), and 200 in handicraft production (75% time).
Similarly, temporary employment is expected to be created for 2,200 persons: 1,200 in rattan plantation, intercropping and rattan harvesting, 500 in Lung harvesting, and 500 through forest enrichment. By the end of the project term, beneficiaries will have generated additional income of about 1 million USD, with 75% earned by women. Given the importance and potential of the sector, from local to national and regional level, experiences generated by the project have a high potential for up-scaling and replication in other sectors.

participating-org.narrative:
Duc Phong is a private enterprise that was established on 15 March 1993 with its former entity of the Enterprise of Producing and Trading of Exporting Bamboo Products and its name was changed into Duc Phong Co., Ltd since August 2001 (with the Business register number 27000/86. The main business of the company is producing, processing and vocational training of bamboo handicraft products forexporting.
Duc Phong Limited Company is the largest handicraft making company in Nghe An province, with total revenue reached overUS$1.2 million in 2013, exported more than 850,000 products to Asia, Europe, and America; The supply areas of Duc Phong company include the 4 project districts of the Rattan/Bamboo project. From October 2013 to March 2014, the companypurchased 1200 tons of raw Lung in Oxfam#s project area. Duc Phong company has provided training and developed more than 100 craft villages in Nghe An, including41 villages making bamboo and rattan products for export, an achievement highly recognized bythe Provincial People#s Committee. Since 2001, Duc Phong Company has organized over 900 training courses and provided career guidance for thousands of workers. Besides production, the company has been focusing on product design and changing models in order to get access and expand to new export markets. Over the years, Duc Phong has expanded from a private enterprise with only 5 employees to a big company of 80 employees working in the factory and more than 2000 people working at home in 31 production areas.
Duc Phong has experience working with internationalNGO on community development for Lung sector, with special focus on handicraft making and capacity building on business developmentskills. During the designing and preparation of the rattan/bamboo project proposal, Oxfam also consulted Duc Phong in getting a perspective from a private enterprise. Since the kick-off of the project, Duc Phong has been one of the active participants in our workshops and experience sharing sessions.
In this project, Duc Phong will be responsible mainly for farmers training in the growing, sustainable harvesting, processing and enrichment technique for Lung bamboo, as well as improving capacity of local people in handicraft production and marketing.
